# Analysis of ğŸ’»â”‚developers Channel

## 1. Summary
The chat segment is brief and contains limited technical discussion. 3rdEyeVisuals shared progress on modifying the core system to support direct .js file uploads as apps, alongside the existing .hyp bundle format. This modification allows users unfamiliar with .hyp bundles to use the base HYP BUNDLER to create and bundle their applications. While the sidebar apps menu was updated to recognize .js files as apps, the Layers world view doesn't detect these files due to missing metadata that would be present in .hyp bundles. 3rdEyeVisuals is seeking guidance on whether to further modify the core files to fully support .js apps and whether their approach is correct. MetaRick mentioned having examples to share later, but no technical details were provided.

## 2. FAQ
Q: Would it be worth modifying the core files some more to fully support straight .js apps? (asked by 3rdEyeVisuals) A: Unanswered
Q: Am I going about this wrong? (asked by 3rdEyeVisuals) A: Unanswered

## 3. Help Interactions
None identified in this chat segment.

## 4. Action Items
Technical: Evaluate whether to modify core files to fully support direct .js files as apps | Description: Consider updating the Layers world view to recognize .js files despite missing metadata | Mentioned By: 3rdEyeVisuals
Technical: Upload example files that "do different things" | Description: Share promised example files with the community | Mentioned By: MetaRick
Documentation: Document the process of using .js files with the HYP BUNDLER | Description: Create documentation for users unfamiliar with .hyp bundles | Mentioned By: 3rdEyeVisuals

# Discord Chat Analysis

## 1. Summary
The chat segment primarily discusses the status of Hyperfy's v1 (Legacy) platform. Ash mentions that v1 has been running smoothly for almost a year without requiring maintenance, and he's working on relearning how it functions. He later announces that "v1 is back baby!" suggesting a successful relaunch or restoration of the platform. Agent12 expresses appreciation for v1's token-gated features and activity notifications that help them know when to engage with visitors in their virtual world. Fibelius suggests that v1 could be maintained as an open-source project, noting that while tech enthusiasts might view it as outdated, many creators would value a stable platform for their work. The conversation indicates that v1 has distinct features from v2, with some users preferring the older version despite its technical limitations.

## 2. FAQ
Q: Legacy back up soon? (asked by Harambe Advocate) A: v1 is back baby! (answered by ash)
Q: Have you played around with V2 at all? (asked by 3rdEyeVisuals) A: No I dont know how to code. Not really interested in learning code either (answered by Harambe Advocate)
Q: OS v1 (asked by Fibelius) A: its extremely hard to run haha (answered by ash)

## 3. Help Interactions
Helper: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“ | Helpee: Harambe Advocate | Context: Harambe expressed inability to code for V2 | Resolution: ğ•½ğ–”ğ–šğ–˜ğ–™ğ–†ğ–“ sent a direct message, presumably with assistance

## 4. Action Items
Technical: Maintain v1 platform functionality | Description: Continue supporting the legacy version that users value for token-gated features | Mentioned By: ash
Feature: Activity notifications for world owners | Description: Preserve the feature that notifies creators when visitors are active in their worlds | Mentioned By: Agent12
Technical: Consider open-source approach for v1 | Description: Evaluate possibility of making v1 open source for community maintenance | Mentioned By: Fibelius

The chat segment is brief and focuses on a user seeking information about objects that can make avatars jump higher in a virtual environment. Specifically, Nicola Bertoglio inquired about implementing a "jumper" functionality for non-admin avatars. Dhin initially suggested a book object that enables flips or double jumps when activated with the F key, but this didn't meet Nicola's needs. Dhin then correctly identified that Nicola was looking for a trampoline-like object and shared a resource, which Nicola confirmed was what they needed.
